title: How many US adult and pediatric hospital admissions with confirmed COVID-19 cases will there be for the week ending 5 June 2021?
preds:
Date
March 7, 2021
State (or territory)
56
New tests
1,170,059
Cases (confirmed plus probable)
28,756,489
Negative PCR tests (people)
74,582,825
Currently hospitalized/Now hospitalized
40,199
Deaths (confirmed and probable)
515,151
Total test results
363,825,123

At 21,097 as of May 29th, declining at a rate of around 300 a day. Which would put it around 19,000 on June 5th. But the rate of decline has slowed recently, so I'm giving a 1 in 4 chance the decline halts or reverses. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

23,078 as of 5/22 with 2 weeks left, current rate of decline is 444 a day. Puts it on pace for about 17k, but the rate of decline may have dropped a little bit recently so leaving about a 1 in 3 chance for the 20k to 30k range. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

I feel the crowd forecast is a bit too conservative, and my forecast seems like a cop-out. But as as of May 15, rolling weekly numbers are ~26k. Over a period of 3 weeks, 30% reduction seems like a coin toss, especially since case reduction has been significant.

26.4k as of May 15th. If the recent trend held the rest of the period it would be at 13.3k. I would guess the recent steep decline will level off a bit before the question ends and could even reverse, so I'm leaving plenty of weight on the 20k to 30k bucket and a 1 in 10 chance for the 30k to 40k bucket. Data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing
31.2k as of May 8th, trending down with a reduction of about 500 hospitalizations a day. Data: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing
I'm employing wishful thinking here. Hoping more of those eligible take the vaccine. I worry, however, about people lowering their guard.

The numbers would decay exponentially, if the pandemic would die off. So care should be taken since simple extrapolation, that we use
so often, would underestimate the strength of the decay.

Drawing upon this sheet https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit#gid=0 and past trends + diminishing returns of vaccinations, I came up with these likelihoods thanks to rough estimates.

At 35k as of May 1 and on a decline, though the decline may have been slowing over the last few days. I think there's a good chance that hospitalizations continue on a steady decline as more of the population gets vaccinated and more second doses are given out. A decline of 500 a day is what I would put for the optimistic end, putting it around 20k. A decline of a few hundred a day I think is most likely, which would put it in the 20 to 30 range. Spreadsheet with the data up to May 1 (open in microsoft edge or another browser if Google chrome can't open it): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing
